title.narrative: Kissi Women's Enhancement Project in Kailahun District

description.narrative: Placement of animals, training in Cornerstones, Leadership, Crop and Livestock Integration, Animal Wellbeing, Provision of seeds (Rice and Groundnut), Veterinary Support, Exchange Visits, Sensitization HIV/AIDs, Water and Sanitation and the Environment, influencing policies, systems and practices. Provision of high yielding cassava cuttings

The Kissi Women’s Enhancement Project in Kailahun District is a three-year goat project aimed at improving the livelihoods of vulnerable rural women, particularly women heads of households in three Kissi chiefdoms, namely Kissi Karma, Kissi Teng and Kissi Tongi. The objectives include providing a new source of livelihood, increasing income, generating supplementary sources of nutrition, increasing knowledge and skills of women in livestock management, and enhancing women’s leadership and decision making capacity. Goats are prolific and given their low management cost, as well as high nutritional value, they are an appropriate choice for the target project participants. The project will distribute 960 goats, and each participating family will receive three does and one buck. In addition to the goats, the project will also establish seed banks for increased crop production. The project will also distribute 240 bushels of rice/groundnut. Through Heifer Sierra Leone’s partnership with the International Institute for Tropical Agriculture (IITA), a total of 23,040 bundles of improved and high yielding cassava cuttings will also be distributed to all participating families. Participants will receive training in improved livestock husbandry and crop and livestock integration. Veterinary drugs, equipment and community-based veterinary support services will be provided for each group. The project will employ and provide training to Community Facilitators who will then monitor and supervise project implementation. The project will benefit a total of 720 families—240 original families and another 480 families who will benefit through Passing on the Gift— and it is estimated to support a total of 5,760 beneficiaries with an average family size of eight by the end of the three-year period.
